case_data.name: NAACP v. San Jose
case_data.summary:
On March 11, 2021, the NAACP and several individuals filed this class-action lawsuit against the city of San Jose and public officials in the United States Northern District Court of California. The plaintiffs stated that they were peacefully protesting police brutality and institutionalized racism on May 29-31, 2020 when San Jose police fired impact munitions and attacked them with flash-bang grenades, chemical weapons, and batons. The plaintiffs contended that the defendants had exhibited a long history of targeting Black, Brown, and Muslim communities and that the use of force in these protests was racially motivated. 

The plaintiffs sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights to free speech and association, their Fourth Amendment rights to be free from unlawful arrest and excessive force, and their Fourteenth Amendment right to equal protection. The plaintiffs brought similar claims under state constitution equivalents of these provisions. The plaintiffs also brought claims under the ADA and Rehabilitation Act, arguing that the defendants’ policing practices failed to make reasonable modifications that allowed people with disabilities to participate in protests. Finally, the plaintiffs sued under a variety of state laws, including tort claims like assault and negligence. The lawsuit sought declaratory relief stating that the defendants’ policing practices were unconstitutional, as well as preliminary and permanent injunctive relief enjoining the defendants from engaging in the same behavior in the future. The class members also sought compensatory damages.

The case was assigned to Judge Phyllis Jean Hamilton of the Northern District of California. 

On June 7, 2021, the defendants moved to dismiss the suit, making arguments for qualified immunity, lack of supervisory liability, and failure to state plausible claims under the various constitutional provisions. 

On September 24, 2021, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ Fourteenth Amendment claims that they were targeted on the basis of race and denied “freedom of movement.” It likewise dismissed a curfew-related claim under the First Amendment with regard to most, but not all, defendants. The court also dismissed the plaintiffs’ claim that the defendants engaged in a conspiracy to violate their constitutional rights. However, the court largely denied the defendants’ motion to dismiss, and it specifically decided to delay its assessment of whether the defendants were entitled to qualified immunity until summary judgment so as to permit factual development in discovery.

Thus, thirteen of the plaintiffs’ causes of action persisted. These causes of action included the plaintiffs’ requests for injunctive and declaratory relief, which were not at issue in the motion to dismiss. The plaintiffs’ state law claims also remained, as did some claims under the First Amendment, claims under the Fourth Amendment for excessive force and wrongful arrest, an allegation of failure to intervene, an alleged violation of the ADA, tort claims for assault and battery, certain of the plaintiffs’ cause of action for false arrest, and an action for negligence.

On February 23, 2023, the court held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ motion for class certification. The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, amending the plaintiffs and defendants to the case and removing three counts as claims for relief on February 27, 2023. 

On April 7, 2023, Judge Hamiliton denied certifying the plaintiffs as a class because the plaintiffs did not show that common issues would predominate over individual issues and that the defendants’ conduct did not generally apply to the class.

The defendants, on April 14, 2023, filed a motion for summary judgment. In the motion, the defendants alleged that the plaintiffs excessive force claims are a product of guesswork, they have no evidence to suggest their First Amendment claims, they have not indicated one federal disability law that was not accommodated, and their state claims fail for the same reasons their federal claims purportedly fail. 

Judge Hamilton, on August 3, 2023, Judge Hamiliton granted in part and denied in part the defendants’ motion for summary judgment, considering the various claims alleged by the various plaintiffs against each of the defendants. 

On August 7, 2023, Judge Hamilton set a settlement conference before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler. On August 23, 2023, the case settled as to one plaintiff, and the other four plaintiffs presented proposals of settlement to each other that were to be presented to the City Council on August 29, 2023. 

On August 29, 2023, the entire case settled before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler, subject to ordinary contingency of final approval by the governing authorities. The Clearinghouse was unable to find the settlement agreement; however, the Partnership for Civil Justice Fund indicated that the San Jose City Council approved a $3.35 million settlement on September 12, 2023.

The plaintiffs, on October 19, 2023, filed a stipulation for dismissal, dismissing the action with prejudice. All parties were to bear their own costs. 

The case is closed.
case_data.summary_short: The NAACP and several individuals sued the city of San Jose and political officials for policing tactics that allegedly deprived them of their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. The plaintiffs, protesting systemic racism in policing, alleged that the police used excessive force in a racially motivated manner to end the protests. While the plaintiffs sought class certification, the court denied certifying the class, because the plaintiffs did not show that common issues would predominate over individual issues. Judge Hamilton granted in part and denied in part the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. The case was then sent for settlement conferencing. The case was settled on August 29, 2023. On September 12, 2023, San Jose City Council approved a $3.35 million settlement agreement.
case_data.summary_tiny: Just added to the Clearinghouse - @NAACP sued the city of San Jose for allegedly unconstitutional police practices being used against peaceful protestors.

of the claims or defenses of the class.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(3).  And fourth, the class 
20 
representative(s) must be able to protect fairly and adequately the interests of all 
21 
members of the class.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(4).  The parties moving for class certification 
22 
bear the burden of establishing that the Rule 23(a) requirements are satisfied.  Gen'l Tel. 
23 
Co. of Southwest v. Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 156 (1982); see also Dukes, 564 U.S. at 350. 
24 
If all four prerequisites of Rule 23(a) are satisfied, the court must also determine 
25 
whether to certify the class under one of the three subsections of Rule 23(b), pursuant to 
26 
which the named plaintiffs must establish that either (1) that there is a risk of substantial 
27 
prejudice from separate actions; or (2) that declaratory or injunctive relief benefitting the 
28 
6 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 7 of 13
 
1  class as a whole would be appropriate; or (3) that common questions of law or fact 
2  common to the class predominate and that a class action is superior to other methods 
3  available for adjudicating the controversy at issue.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b). 
4  The court does not make a preliminary inquiry into the merits of plaintiffs' claims in 
5  determining whether to certify a class.  Eisen v. Carlisle & Jacquelin, 417 U.S. 156, 177 
6  (1974).  The court will, however, scrutinize plaintiffs’ legal causes of action to determine 
7  whether they are suitable for resolution on a class-wide basis.  See, e.g., Moore v. 
8  Hughes Helicopters, Inc., 708 F.2d 475, 480 (9th Cir. 1983).  Making such a 
9  determination will sometimes require examining issues that overlap with the merits.  See 
10  Dukes, 564 U.S. at 350-51 (acknowledging that court's “rigorous analysis” will frequently 
11  entail some overlap with merits of plaintiff's underlying claim).  
 a  12  The court will consider matters beyond the pleadings, if necessary, in order to 
urtni
oor 13  ascertain whether the asserted claims or defenses are susceptible of resolution on a 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  class wide basis.  See McCarthy v. Kleindienst, 741 F.2d 1406, 1419 n.8 (D.C. Cir. 
Dict  15  1984). 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  B.  Analysis 
t
S 
n
d er 17  1.  Damages class 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  As set forth above, in order to certify a damages class under Rule 23(b)(3), 
N
19  plaintiffs must show that the four Rule 23(a) requirements are met, and must also show 
20  that “common questions of law or fact common to the class predominate and that a class 
21  action is superior to other methods available for adjudicating the controversy at issue.”  
22  Because, as will be set forth below, the court finds this matter can be determined on the 
23  basis of the Rule 23(b) showing alone, the court does not reach the Rule 23(a) showing.   
24  Plaintiffs argue that their claims present “common questions of law and fact 
25  regarding the city’s customs and policies related to policing public protest” that 
26  predominate over any individual issues.  Specifically, plaintiffs identify the following 
27  common questions: (1) did the SJPD have an unconstitutional custom and practice of 
28  using indiscriminate and other excessive force against peaceful protestors, as evidenced 
7 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 8 of 13
 
1  during the Floyd protests, (2) was there a failure to train the city’s employees in the 
2  proper use of force, and a failure to adequately supervise their use of force, and (3) were 
3  the foregoing violations authorized by city policymakers because no discipline was 
4  imposed for any of the excessive force and violations of written SJPD policies.  Dkt. 87 at 
5  20-21.   
6    Plaintiffs argue that another district court, on similar facts, granted a motion for 
7  class certification after finding that common issues predominated over individual ones.  
8  See Multi-Ethnic Immigrant Workers Org. Network v. City of Los Angeles, 246 F.R.D. 621 
9  (C.D. Cal. 2007) (“MIWON”). 
10  The MIWON court found that the predominance requirement was indeed met as to 
11  plaintiffs’ Fourth Amendment excessive force claims: 
 
urt nia  12  The Court recognizes that the conduct of individual officers in the field may

t ali reasonable under the circumstances for a particular officer to fire less-lethal 
stricof C 14  masu pnuitisohnins,g u asned h sish obvaitnogn.  to strike people, or use other forms of force, such 
s Dirict  15   
est Nonetheless, the individual issues share a common source: the command 
atDi 16 
t decisions to disperse the crowd and to authorize the use of less-lethal 
S 
n
d er 17  munitions if the crowd’s behavior warranted it.  LAPD Report at 8, 34–35.  
e
th Because the legality of these command decisions is the overriding common 
nirt
Uo 18  question, the predominance requirement is met as to the Fourth 
N
Amendment claim. 
19 
MIWON at 635.   
20 
  That final sentence – the focus on the command decisions, rather than the actions 
21 
of individual officers – is the key to the court’s conclusion on predominance.  Earlier in the 
22 
same section, the MIWON court emphasized that “plaintiffs focus on the LAPD 
23 
commanders’ authorization of ‘less lethal’ force (as distinct from the application of such 
24 
force).”  Id. (emphasis in original).  Also of note is that, in MIWON, the plaintiffs filed suit 
25 
against only the City of Los Angeles, William Bratton (the Chief of Police), Cayler Carter 
26 
(Deputy Chief of Police), and Louis Gray (a LAPD commander).  Id. at 624.3 
27 
 
28 
3 The MIWON opinion also states that Does 1 through 10 were named as defendants, but 
8 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 9 of 13
 
1    In contrast, there is no such narrow focus on the command decisions in the 
2  present case.  Plaintiffs are pursuing claims against not only the defendants who made 
3  the high-level decisions to authorize force, but also the officers who applied such force.  
4  That is the key distinction between this case and MIWON. 
5  The distinction can be most clearly seen when looking at plaintiffs’ excessive force 
6  claim under section 1983.  See Dkt. 108, ¶¶ 222-226.  Plaintiffs assert the claim on behalf 
7  of all plaintiffs against defendants City of San Jose, Garcia, Knopf, Dwyer, Matchett, and 
8  Tassio, those defendants having been involved in the authorization of force, but plaintiffs 
9  also assert the excessive force claim against individual officers who were involved in the 
10  application of force.  Specifically, the excessive force claim is asserted by plaintiff Acosta 
11  against defendants Yuen, Nguyen, Grodin, Lopez, and Lynch; by plaintiff Naemeh 
 a  12  against defendants Orabuena, Weber, Situ, and Lopez; by plaintiff Swift against 
urtni
oor 13  defendants Curry, Silva, and Ayala; by plaintiff Cañas against defendants Yuen and 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  Lopez; by plaintiff Vasquez against defendants Yuen, Simonini, and Lopez; by plaintiff 
Dict  15  Allen against defendants Yuen and Lopez; by plaintiff Riles against defendant Simonini; 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  by plaintiff Flores against defendants Gaona and Grodin; by plaintiff Cuellar against

S 
n
d er 17  defendants Simonini, Adgar, Nguyen, Grodin, Moran, and Lynch; and by plaintiff 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  Maldonado against defendant Lagorio.  See id.  The same non-overlapping sets of 
N
19  plaintiffs and defendants are listed for plaintiffs’ state law claims for assault and battery, 
20  negligence, and violation of the Ralph Act.  See id., ¶¶ 268-284.    
21    Because this case involves not only common claims regarding the authorization of 
22  force, but also individual claims arising out of each individual application of force, the 
23  court finds that the reasoning of MIWON is distinguishable, and accordingly, the court 
24  concludes that plaintiffs have not shown that common issues would predominate over 
25  individual issues as required by Rule 23(b)(3).  For that reason, plaintiffs’ motion for 
26  certification of a damages class is DENIED.  As discussed above, the court need not

the opinion provides no indication that any Doe substitutions were ultimately made.

1  address the Rule 23(a) factors as they relate to the proposed damages class. 
2  2.  Injunctive relief class 
3  Certification under Rule 23(b)(2) is appropriate where the opposing party “has 
4  acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the class, thereby making 
5  appropriate final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief with respect to the 
6  class as a whole.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2). 
7    As an initial matter, the court points out the lack of clarity in plaintiffs’ pursuit of 
8  injunctive relief.  Neither the complaint nor the amended complaint sets forth the scope or 
9  nature of the injunction that plaintiffs are seeking.  Plaintiffs’ class certification motion 
10  similarly fails to specify what type of injunction they seek the court to impose.  In their 
11  reply brief, plaintiffs state for the first time that they are seeking to enjoin “the 
 a  12  indiscriminate use of impact munitions and batons on peaceful protestors,” and “to 
urtni
oor 13  ensure the written policy is followed, plaintiffs also seek training and accountability 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  measures.”  Dkt. 103 at 16.  No further details are provided.  
Dict  15    Even putting aside any vagueness problems, the larger obstacle to certification 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  under Rule 23(b)(2) is the cross-cutting, non-overlapping nature of the various claims 
t
S 
n
d er 17  brought by different plaintiffs against different defendants.  In contrast, in the MIWON 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  case cited above, the court certified an injunctive relief class in a case where plaintiffs 
N
19  brought suit against only LAPD command personnel, and “focus[ed] on the LAPD 
20  commanders’ authorization of ‘less lethal’ force (as distinct from the application of such 
21  force).”  MIWON, 246 F.R.D. at 635 (emphasis in original).  However, as discussed 
22  above, the plaintiffs in this case did not focus their claims in a similar manner.  Rather 
23  than bringing suit against only command personnel and focusing on their authorization of 
24  force, the plaintiffs in this case challenge both the authorization of force by command 
25  personnel as well as the application of force by line officers.  The number of individual, 
26  non-overlapping claims brought by different sets of plaintiffs against different sets of 
27  defendants prevents the court from concluding that defendants’ conduct applies generally 
28  to the class, and accordingly, plaintiffs’ motion for certification of an injunctive relief class 
10 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 11 of 13
 
1  is DENIED.  As discussed above, the court need not address the Rule 23(a) factors as 
2  they apply to the proposed injunctive relief class.   
3  C.  Other issues 
4  1.  Discovery letter brief 
5    Also before the court is a discovery dispute between the parties.  The discovery 
6  dispute is a request by defendants to “preclude plaintiff Acosta’s claim for future income 
7  loss based on documents plaintiffs did not provide in initial disclosures or during 
8  discovery.”  Dkt. 102 at 1. 
9  The essence of defendants’ argument is that plaintiffs waited until after the close 
10  of discovery to reveal that plaintiff Acosta would be pursuing damages based on lost 
11  future income.  Dkt. 102 at 1.  Defendants argue that the late disclosure prevents them 
 a  12  from taking discovery from Acosta’s employer and coworkers.  Defendants thus ask for 
urtni
oor 13  an order precluding Acosta from pursuing damages based on lost future income, and 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  from using any documents related to Acosta’s employment that were not provided before 
Dict  15  the close of discovery.  Defendants’ request is made pursuant to Rules 26 and 37.  Rule 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  26 requires a party to disclose damages-related information and to supplement or correct 
t
S 
n
d er 17  those disclosures in a timely manner, and Rule 37 forbids the use at trial of information 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  that was not properly disclosed, unless the failure to disclose was substantially justified or 
N
19  harmless.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 37; R & R Sails, Inc. v. Insurance Co. of Penn., 673 
20  F.3d 1240, 1246 (9th Cir. 2012).   
21    Plaintiffs argue that “Acosta’s discovery responses have always made clear that 
22  he might have a future wage loss claim,” and cite to interrogatory responses stating that 
23  “he is struggling to keep up at his demanding job” and “the amount of any future wage 
24  loss is undetermined at this time.”  Dkt. 102 at 4.  Plaintiffs argue that “when defendants 
25  requested documents supporting a claim for loss of income or earning capacity in 
26  October 2021, no such documents existed and any future wage loss was speculative,” 
27  but “in October and November 2022, events transpired that made it more likely that Mr. 
28  Acosta could suffer an injury-related future income loss.”  Id.  Specifically, plaintiffs point 
11 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 12 of 13
 
1  to Acosta’s job performance review in October 2022 that was “significantly less positive” 
2  than prior reviews, and to news of a “tech downturn” in November 2022, arguing that 
3  those events turned a speculative wage-loss claim into a non-speculative one.  
4  Overall, plaintiffs have not shown that their failure to timely disclose was 
5  substantially justified or harmless.  Essentially, they argue that Acosta was aware of his 
6  own limitations, but was not aware that his supervisor had noticed until the performance 
7  review in October 2022.  First of all, the fact discovery cutoff was not until November 14, 
8  2022, so plaintiffs still could have made the disclosure before the close of discovery – but 
9  more importantly, Acosta himself is in the best position to assess whether he feels that 
10  his work performance was affected, and by plaintiffs’ own account, he was aware of that 
11  at least as early as July 2022.  Accordingly, defendants’ request to preclude the claim of 
 a  12  future income loss and the late-produced documents is GRANTED.   
urtni
oor 13  2.  Motion to seal 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  In connection with the discovery letter brief, plaintiffs filed a motion to seal.  See 
Dict  15  Dkt. 97.  Because the motion sought the sealing of entire exhibits, rather than seeking 
s ri

atDi 16  limited redactions of truly sensitive information, the court denied the motion to seal 
t
S 
n
d er 17  without prejudice.  See Dkt. 100.   
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  Plaintiffs have filed a revised motion to seal, but in addition to seeking the sealing 
N
19  of medical and mental health information, plaintiffs also seek the sealing of information 
20  related to plaintiff’s employment, such as salary information and the names of products 
21  that plaintiff worked on.  See Dkt. 101.   
22  To the extent that plaintiffs seek the sealing of medical and/or mental health 
23  information, the motion to seal is GRANTED.  However, to the extent that plaintiffs seek 
24  the sealing of information related to plaintiff Acosta’s employment, the motion to seal is 
25  DENIED.  Plaintiffs are directed to re-file the exhibits with only medical or mental health 
26  information redacted from public filing. 
27  CONCLUSION 
28  For the foregoing reasons, plaintiffs’ motion for class certification (Dkt. 87) is 
12 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 113   Filed 04/07/23   Page 13 of 13
 
1  DENIED as to both the proposed damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) as well as the 
2  proposed injunctive relief class under Rule 23(b)(2).  Defendants’ discovery request to 
3  preclude evidence based on Acosta’s future lost income (Dkt. 102) is GRANTED, and 
4  plaintiffs’ motion to seal (Dkt. 101) is GRANTED in part and DENIED in part.   
5    IT IS SO ORDERED.

documents.text:
Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 1 of 14
 
1   
2  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
3  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
4   
 
5  NAACP OF SAN JOSE/ SILICON 
VALLEY, et al.,  Case No. 21-cv-01705-PJH    
6   
Plaintiffs,   
7  ORDER RE MOTION TO AMEND 
v.  COMPLAINT AND DISCOVERY 
8    LETTER BRIEFS 
CITY OF SAN JOSE, et al., 
9  Re: Dkt. No. 70, 76, 79 
Defendants. 
10   
 
11    
 a  12    Plaintiffs’ motion to amend the complaint came on for hearing on November 10, 
urtni
oor 13  2022.  Plaintiffs appeared through their counsel, Rachel Lederman.  Defendants 
Cf
t ali
cC
striof  14  appeared through their counsel, James Huang and Ardell Johnson.  Having read the 
Dict  15  papers filed by the parties and carefully considered their arguments and relevant 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  authority, and good cause appearing, the court hereby rules as follows. 
t
S 
n
d er 17  BACKGROUND 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18    This is a civil rights case arising out of the May 2020 protests in response to the 
N
19  killing of George Floyd by police.  The original complaint in this case asserted claims 
20  against the City of San Jose and nine individual defendants, which included members of 
21  the San Jose Police Department.  The complaint also named as defendants 100 fictitious 
22  Doe defendants, which included police officers who were alleged to have used force 
23  against plaintiffs but who could not be identified, as well as Doe defendants who 
24  supervised the officers.  See, e.g., Dkt. 3, ¶¶ 39, 65, 104.    
25    Plaintiffs now move to amend the complaint to substitute certain Doe defendants, 
26  arguing that the allegations against those defendants relate back to the filing of the 
27  original complaint. 
28  Defendants challenge five categories of additions: (1) “‘directing’ Doe officers 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 2 of 14
 
1  allegations against Asuelo,” (2) “‘false identification’ allegations against Bird1, Weber, and 
2  Erbes,” (3) “blanket ‘supervisory’-type First Amendment suppression allegations against 
3  Knopf, Matchett, Lagorio, Lynch, and Erbes,” (4) “‘failure to intervene’ allegations against 
4  Simonini, Gaona, Adgar, Moran, Nguyen, and Grodin,” and (5) “the single factually 
5  devoid and conclusory sentence against defendant Preuss.”  See Dkt. 72 at 8-13.  
6  DISCUSSION 
7  A.  Legal Standard 
8  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 requires that a plaintiff obtain either consent of 
9  the defendant or leave of court to amend its complaint once the defendant has answered, 
10  but “leave shall be freely given when justice so requires.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a).  Rule 
11  15(c) further provides that “[a]n amendment to a pleading relates back to the date of the 
 a  12  original pleading when,” among other requirements, “the amendment asserts a claim or 
urtni
oor 13  defense that arose out of the conduct, transaction, or occurrence set out – or attempted 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  to be set out – in the original pleading.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(c).   
Dict  15  The Ninth Circuit has held that federal courts must “consider both federal and state 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  law and employ whichever affords the ‘more permissive’ relation back standard.”  Butler 
t
S 
n
d er 17  v. Nat’l Community Renaissance of California, 766 F.3d 1191, 1201 (9th Cir. 2014).  
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  California Code of Civil Procedure section 474 specifically covers situations “[w]hen the 
N
19  plaintiff is ignorant of the name of a defendant” and must designate the defendant by a 
20  fictitious name until “his true name is discovered,” at which time “the pleading or 
21  proceeding must be amended accordingly.”  Cal. C.C.P. § 474.   
22  California courts have held that “the relation-back doctrine can save an amended 
23  complaint that identifies a fictitiously-named defendant and asserts a cause of action 
24  against that defendant only if: (1) the amended complaint is based on the same general 
25  state of facts as the original; (2) the original complaint stated a valid cause of action 
26 
 
27 
1 Plaintiffs concede that Bird was “incorrectly named” and that he should be removed 
from the complaint.  See Dkt. 73 at 7.  Plaintiffs also acknowledge that Jacob Morris and 
28 
Fnu (“first name unknown”) Roude were named in error.  See id. 
2 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 3 of 14
 
1  against the now-identified defendant; and (3) the plaintiff was “genuinely ignorant” of the 
2  defendant's identity or the facts rendering defendant liable when the original complaint 
3  was filed.”  Eghtesad v. State Farm General Insurance Company, 51 Cal.App.5th 406, 
4  415 (2020) (citing Austin v. Massachusetts Bonding & Insurance Co., 56 Cal.2d 596, 600-
5  601 (1961)). 
6  B.  Analysis 
7  Before applying the relation-back doctrine to the current motion to amend, the 
8  court must set forth some of the relevant procedural background.  The original complaint 
9  in this case asserted sixteen causes of action against the City of San Jose, nine 
10  individual defendants, and the Doe defendants.  See Dkt. 3.  When defendants filed a 
11  motion to dismiss the complaint, the court issued an order in advance of the hearing, 
 a  12  stating that “the complaint is unclear in stating which claims are being asserted by which 
urtni
oor 13  plaintiffs against which defendants.”  See Dkt. 35.  The court directed plaintiffs to file a 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  chart specifically listing each plaintiff and each defendant for each cause of action, and 
Dict  15  further asked plaintiffs’ counsel to clarify the scope of their claims at the hearing.  See 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  Dkt. 37; Dkt. 44 at 23-25.   
t
S 
n
d er 17  Despite the court’s previous attempts to bring clarity as to the scope of the claims 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  asserted, the original complaint still remains unclear as to exactly which claims were 
N
19  intended to be asserted against Doe defendants.  In particular, the court notes that only 
20  certain causes of action in the original complaint – such as the eighth cause of action for 
21  failure to intervene in violation of section 1983 – specifically listed Doe defendants as part 
22  of the group of defendants against whom the claim was asserted.  See Dkt. 3 at 62.  
23  Other claims in the original complaint, such as the third cause of action for violation of 
24  First Amendment rights under section 1983 and the fourth cause of action for excessive 
25  force under section 1983, did not list any plaintiffs or defendants at all, let alone Doe 
26  defendants.  Because of the complaint’s lack of clarity – which could have been avoided 
27  if plaintiffs had simply listed each plaintiff and each defendant, including Does, for each 
28  cause of action – the court must look more closely at the original complaint’s allegations 
3 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 4 of 14
 
1  to determine which claims were adequately asserted against Doe defendants, such that 
2  the proposed amendments would relate back.   
3  Moreover, compounding the lack of clarity, plaintiffs’ current proposed amended 
4  complaint repeats many of the same problems as the original complaint.  In particular, 
5  many of the causes of action again do not set forth which plaintiffs are asserting the claim 
6  or against which defendants the claim is intended to be asserted.  See, e.g., Dkt. 70-1 at 
7  57 (third cause of action for violation of the First Amendment under section 1983, no 
8  plaintiffs or defendants listed in heading); 58 (fourth cause of action for excessive force, 
9  no plaintiffs or defendants listed); 60 (seventh cause of action for violation of the 
10  Americans with Disabilities Act, no plaintiffs or defendants listed in heading).   
11    As a separate initial matter, the court also notes that plaintiffs submitted a 
 a  12  proposed amended complaint along with their motion to amend, but then submitted a 
urtni
oor 13  “corrected” proposed amended complaint along with their reply brief, purporting to add 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  new allegations against defendant Preuss.  Plaintiffs’ attempt to add new allegations in 
Dict  15  their reply brief was improper and deprived defendants an opportunity to respond, and 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  thus, the “corrected” proposed amended complaint (Dkt. 73-1) will be STRICKEN and will 
t
S 
n
d er 17  not be considered by the court on this motion.  Instead, the court will consider only the 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  proposed additions contained within the earlier-filed proposed amended complaint (Dkt. 
N
19  70-1).   
20  1.  Category (1) – “‘directing’ allegations as to defendant Asuelo” 
21  The first category of additions challenged by defendants is the “‘directing’ Doe 
22  officers allegations against Asuelo.”  See Dkt. 72 at 9.  Defendants argue that defendant 
23  Asuelo “is added as having ‘directed’ City of San Jose police officers who shoved Ms. 
24  Cartwright hard in the chest on May 29, shot her in the right knee, left calf, and finger on 
25  May 30, and wrongfully arrested her on May 31.”  Id. (quoting Dkt. 70-1, ¶ 20).  
26  Defendants argue that the Doe substitution does not relate back to the original complaint, 
27  which does not include any “directing” allegations and instead alleges only that officers 
28  shoved, shot, and wrongfully arrested Cartwright.  See Dkt. 72 at 9 (citing Dkt. 3, ¶ 20).   
4 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 5 of 14
 
1    The proposed amended complaint is not entirely clear in stating which causes of 
2  action are intended to be asserted against proposed defendant Asuelo.  At minimum, the 
3  proposed amended complaint seeks to add Asuelo as a defendant to the fifth cause of 
4  action for wrongful arrest under federal law and the twelfth cause of action for false arrest 
5  under state law.  See Dkt. 70-1 at 58, 65.  However, as mentioned above, the proposed 
6  amended complaint does not list any specific defendants for claims such as the fourth 
7  cause of action for excessive force, making it unclear as to whether plaintiffs intend to 
8  assert that claim, or other claims with a similar lack of detail, against Asuelo.  And as also 
9  mentioned above, the original complaint was unclear as to exactly which claims were 
10  asserted against Doe defendants.  To determine whether the new allegations against 
11  Asuelo do indeed relate back to the original complaint, the court will need to compare the 
 a  12  new proposed allegations to the allegations made against Doe defendants in the original 
urtni

28    Also before the court is the parties’ joint discovery letter brief regarding plaintiffs’ 
12 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 81   Filed 12/06/22   Page 13 of 14
 
1  interrogatory responses.  As stated at the hearing, plaintiffs’ objections to the 
2  interrogatories are OVERRULED.  While plaintiffs are correct that an interrogatory 
3  seeking the factual basis for request-for-admission denials is properly treated as a 
4  compound interrogatory, plaintiffs’ argument ignores the fact that each defendant may 
5  serve their own interrogatories, and to the extent that any one defendant exceeded their 
6  limit, courts have been willing to deem any excess interrogatories as coming from the 
7  other defendants.  See, e.g., Trevino v. ACB American, 232 F.R.D. 612, 614 (N.D. Cal. 
8  2006) (“the court will treat the first 25 interrogatories as served by” the first plaintiff, and 
9  the remaining interrogatories were “treated as served” by another plaintiff); see also 
10  Safeco of America v. Rawstron, 181 F.R.D. 441, 445 (C.D. Cal. 1998) (“Allowing service 
11  of an interrogatory which requests disclosure of all of the information on which the denials 
 a  12  of each of 50 requests for admissions were based, however, essentially transforms each 
urtni
oor 13  request for admission into an interrogatory”); Chapman v. California Dept. of Education, 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  2002 WL 32854376, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Feb. 6, 2002) (“If the interrogatory relates to distinct 
Dict  15  and separate requests for admission, the interrogatories should be treated as the same 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  number of subparts as there are requests for admission.”) 
t
S 
n
d er 17  Accordingly, given the number of defendants in this case, the court finds no basis 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  for concluding that the number of interrogatories is excessive.  For that reason, plaintiffs’ 
N

20  brief (Dkt. 76) is OVERRULED.

22  November 21.  In the letter, plaintiffs seek leave to take a deposition despite the close of 
23  fact discovery having already occurred on November 14.  Plaintiffs’ request is DENIED.   
24  CONCLUSION

26  in part and DENIED in part, plaintiffs’ objections to compound interrogatories reflected in 
27  the October 27 joint discovery letter brief (Dkt. 76) are OVERRULED, and plaintiffs’ 
28  request to take a deposition after the close of discovery reflected in the November 21 
13

2  Plaintiffs are directed to file a revised proposed amended complaint in accordance 
3  with this order – specifically listing each plaintiff and each defendant named on each

5    IT IS SO ORDERED.

documents.text:
1   
2   
3   
4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
6   
 
7  NAACP OF SAN JOSE/ SILICON 
VALLEY, et al.,  Case No. 21-cv-1705-PJH    
8   
Plaintiffs,   
9  ORDER RE MOTION TO DISMISS 
v. 
10    Re: Dkt. No. 27 
CITY OF SAN JOSE, et al., 
11 
Defendants. 
 a  12   
urtni  
Cofor 13    
t ali
stricof C 14  Defendants’ motion to dismiss came on for hearing before this court on August 12, 
Dict  15  2021.  Plaintiffs NAACP of San Jose/Silicon Valley, San Jose Peace and Justice Center, 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  M. Michael Acosta, Joseph Cañas, Leslie Vasquez, Peter Allen, Shaunn Cartwright, 
t
S 
n
d er 17  Yessica Riles, Jose Gustavo Flores Rodriguez, Alex Lee, Joseph Maldonado, Cindy 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  Cuellar, Mahmoudreza Naemeh, and Megan Swift appeared through their counsel, 
N
19  Rachel Lederman, Tifanei Ressl-Moyer, and James Chanin.  Defendants City of San 
20  Jose, Sam Liccardo, Edgardo Garcia, David Sykes, Jason Dwyer, Ronnie Lopez, Lee 
21  Tassio, Jared Yuen, Sean Michael Curry, and Fnu Delgado appeared through their 
22  counsel, Matthew Pritchard and Yue-Han Chow.  Having read the papers filed by the 
23  parties and carefully considered their arguments and relevant authority, and good cause 
24  appearing, the court hereby rules as follows. 
25  BACKGROUND 
26  This is a civil rights case.  The allegations all arise out of last summer’s protests in 
27  response to the killing of George Floyd.  Specifically, between May 29 and May 31, 2020, 
28  plaintiffs participated in protests in San Jose to “express their view that police brutality 

 
1  and institutionalized racism must end,” and now “seek redress for the violation of their 
2  constitutional rights to assemble, protest, and be free from racial discrimination, disability 
3  discrimination, excessive force, and wrongful arrest.”  Dkt. 3 (Complaint), ¶¶ 2, 3. 
4    There are two “organization plaintiffs” and twelve individual plaintiffs in this case.  
5  The organization plaintiffs are (1) the National Association for the Advancement of 
6  Colored People of San Jose/Silicon Valley (“NAACP”), and (2) the San Jose Peace and 
7  Justice Center (“SJPJC”).  Both organizations allege in the complaint that their 
8  constituents’ rights to speech and assembly were violated, and that the organizations 
9  plan to assist and participate in similar protests in the future and are “fearful that the 
10  same unlawful police actions in response to these and similar protests of institutional 
11  racism and police brutality will be repeated absent injunctive relief.”  Dkt. 3, ¶¶ 14, 15. 
 a  12  Both organizations are plaintiffs for equitable relief only.  Dkt. 37 at 1, n.2.

5  DISCUSSION 
6  A.  Legal Standard 
7  A motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) tests for the 
8  legal sufficiency of the claims alleged in the complaint.  Ileto v. Glock, Inc., 349 F.3d 
9  1191, 1199-1200 (9th Cir. 2003).  Review is limited to the contents of the complaint.  
10  Allarcom Pay Television, Ltd. v. Gen. Instrument Corp., 69 F.3d 381, 385 (9th Cir. 1995).  
11  To survive a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, a complaint generally must 
 a  12  satisfy only the minimal notice pleading requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
urtni
Cofor 13  8, which requires that a complaint include a “short and plain statement of the claim 
t ali
cC
striof  14  showing that the pleader is entitled to relief.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a)(2).   
s Dirict  15  A complaint may be dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) for failure to state a claim if the 
et
s
atDi 16  plaintiff fails to state a cognizable legal theory, or has not alleged sufficient facts to 
t
S 
n
ed er 17  support a cognizable legal theory.  Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Dep't, 901 F.2d 696, 699 
h
t
nirt
UNo 18  (9th Cir. 1990).  The court is to “accept all factual allegations in the complaint as true and 
19  construe the pleadings in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.”  Outdoor 
20  Media Group, Inc. v. City of Beaumont, 506 F.3d 895, 899-900 (9th Cir. 2007).   
21  However, legally conclusory statements, not supported by actual factual 
22  allegations, need not be accepted.  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678-79 (2009).  The 
23  allegations in the complaint “must be enough to raise a right to relief above the 
24  speculative level.”  Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007) (citations 
25  and quotations omitted).  A claim has facial plausibility when the plaintiff pleads factual

e

nirt
Uo 18  1.  Qualified immunity 
N
19    Before addressing the causes of action individually, the court notes that much of 
20  defendants’ motion is based on qualified immunity.  The defense of qualified immunity 
21  protects “government officials . . . from liability for civil damages insofar as their conduct 
22  does not violate clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a 
23  reasonable person would have known.”  Harlow v. Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. 800, 818 (1982).  
24  A court considering a claim of qualified immunity must determine whether the plaintiff has 
25  alleged the deprivation of an actual constitutional right and whether such right was clearly 
26  established such that it would be clear to a reasonable officer that his conduct was 
27  unlawful in the situation he confronted.  See Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223, 236 
28  (2009). 
11 

 
1    While courts may consider qualified immunity at the pleadings stage, the Ninth 
2  Circuit has noted that “[d]etermining claims of qualified immunity at the motion-to-dismiss 
3  stage raises special problems for legal decision making.”  Keates v. Kolie, 883 F.3d 1228, 
4  1234 (9th Cir. 2018) (citing Kwai Fun Wong v. United States, 373 F.3d 952, 956-57 (9th 
5  Cir. 2004)).  The Ninth Circuit has also observed that, by considering qualified immunity 
6  at the pleadings stage, “the courts may be called upon to decide far-reaching 
7  constitutional questions on a nonexistent factual record.”  Kwai Fun Wong, 373 F.3d at 
8  957.   
9    Moreover, as seen above in the Background section of this order, many of the 
10  factual allegations are specific to each plaintiff and not amenable to a blanket ruling of 
11  qualified immunity.  For those reasons, the court is inclined to consider defendants’ 
 a  12  qualified immunity arguments at the summary judgment stage, when the court will have 
urtni
oor 13  the benefit of a developed factual record.  While defendants may ultimately prevail on 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  many of the arguments it makes now with respect to qualified immunity, because the 
Dict  15  qualified immunity analysis often turns on the specific facts of each alleged violation, the 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  court finds that the qualified immunity arguments are better suited to summary judgment.   
t
S 
n
d er 17  2.  Municipal and supervisory liability 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  Defendants’ motion also presents a threshold issue regarding municipal and 
N
19  supervisory liability.  Because these issues are raised in connection with many of the 
20  individual causes of action, the court will first address the parties’ arguments here. 
21    Under Monell v. Dept. of Soc. Servs. of City of New York, a city is not liable for the 
22  torts of its agents unless the city’s policymakers adopted a policy or custom that was the 
23  “moving force” behind the alleged violations.  Monell, 436 U.S. 658, 691 (1978).  The 
24  inadequacy of police training may serve as the basis for liability, but “only where the 
25  failure to train amounts to deliberate indifference to the rights of persons with whom the 
26  police come into contact.”  City of Canton v. Harris, 489 U.S. 378, 388 (1989). 
27  Defendants argue that there was no policy or custom behind the alleged violations, 
28  and further argue that plaintiffs’ “failure to train” theory is not viable because plaintiffs do 
12 

 
1  not allege facts showing that the training program before May 2020 was constitutionally 
2  inadequate.   
3    Plaintiffs point to the following three categories of allegations: (1) defendants 
4  adopted specific policies for a curfew and to allow expanded use of dangerous riot 
5  weapons, (2) defendants encouraged, tolerated, and ratified a series of racist policing 
6  and excessive force incidents over the years, and (3) defendants failed to train officers 
7  despite obvious knowledge of a culture of white supremacist racism and history of 
8  excessive force.  See Dkt. 32 at 19.  Plaintiffs also point to the complaint’s allegations 
9  that city policymakers “changed its policies days before the May 29, 2020 demonstration 
10  to allow use of additional chemical agent devices and allow use of impact munitions that 
11  it had previously prohibited in crowd control situations.”  Dkt. 3, ¶ 192.  Plaintiffs argue 
 a  12  that these allegations support all three theories of Monell liability as used in the Ninth 
urtni
oor 13  Circuit: (1) an unconstitutional custom or policy, (2) deliberately indifferent omission, such 
Cf

20  b.  Curfew 
21  Even in a public forum, the government “may impose reasonable restrictions on 
22  the time, place, or manner of protected speech.”  Ward v. Rock Against Racism, 491 U.S. 
23  781, 791 (1989).  To be constitutional, those restrictions must be: (1) “without reference 
24  to the content of the regulated speech,” i.e., content neutral, (2) “narrowly tailored to 
25  serve a significant government interest,” and must (3) “leave open ample alternative 
26  channels for communication of the information.”  Id.   
27  In this case, the curfew order stated that “no person shall be upon the public 
28  street, avenue, alley, park, or other public place or unimproved public realty within the 
18 

 
1  limits of the City of San Jose” from the hours from 8:30pm to 5:00am.  Dkt. 30, Ex. A.9  
2  The curfew order states that it “shall not apply to police officers, peace officers, 
3  firefighters, or other emergency personnel or civilians engaged in police, emergency, 
4  government work, delivery services, or utility services, nor shall it apply to authorized 
5  representatives of any news service, newspaper, or radio or television station or network, 
6  nor shall it apply to individuals seeking or providing medical care or care for family 
7  members or others.”  Id.

9  neutral.  Thus, the analysis turns on whether plaintiffs have adequately alleged that the 
10  curfew was not narrowly tailored and/or that it did not leave open ample alternative

19  Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.  Excessive force claims are governed by the

21  and quality of the intrusion on the individual’s Fourth Amendment interests” is balanced 
22  against the “countervailing government interests.”  Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386, 395 
23  (1989).  In evaluating the government’s interest, courts look at (1) the severity of the 
24  crime at issue, (2) whether the suspect posed an immediate threat to the safety of the 
25  officers or others, and (3) whether the suspect was actively resisting arrest or attempting 
26  to evade arrest by flight.  Young v. City of Los Angeles, 655 F.3d 1156, 1163 (9th Cir. 
27  2011).

Uo 18  protestors based on their ethnicity, or that similarly situated protestors outside that class 
N
19  received better treatment. 
20  In their opposition, plaintiffs offer only a short response to this argument, arguing 
21  that “police officers targeted demonstrators seeking accountability for police violence 
22  against Black people supports the inference of the defendants’ discriminatory impact and 
23  purpose.”  Dkt. 32 at 26.  Plaintiffs then state that “[a]lternatively, plaintiffs’ First 
24  Amendment claim may provide analogous relief.”  Id.   
25  As discussed above, while plaintiffs’ complaint does adequately allege that 
26  plaintiffs were targeted for their viewpoint, and while that viewpoint relates to the issue of 
27  ethnicity, the complaint does not adequately allege that plaintiffs were targeted for their 
28  own ethnicity.  Thus, while the court previously concluded that plaintiffs have adequately 
25 

 
1  pled a First Amendment claim, it now concludes that plaintiffs have not adequately 
2  alleged an equal protection clam under the Fourteenth Amendment.  Defendants’ motion 
3  to dismiss the sixth cause of action is GRANTED.  Because this claim is substantively 
4  similar to plaintiffs’ third cause of action for viewpoint discrimination, and because 
5  plaintiffs’ opposition brief did not set forth reasons why this claim should proceed, and in 
6  fact acknowledged that the third cause of action may “provide analogous relief,” the 
7  dismissal of the sixth cause of action shall be with prejudice.   
8  7.  Seventh cause of action (freedom of movement) 
9  Defendants argue that there is no standalone cause of action for violation of the 
10  “freedom of movement,” and instead, courts have found laws that unduly restrict 
11  movement to violate either the Due Process or Equal Protection clauses.   
 a  12  Plaintiffs argue that “citizens have a fundamental right of free movement” and that 
urtni
oor 13  the “curfew order was not narrowly tailored nor was it necessary to serve a compelling 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  state interest.”  The opposition contains only two paragraphs on this claim.  Dkt. 32 at 14.   
Dict  15  Defendants’ reply argues that plaintiffs have “effectively abandoned” this claim.   
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  Plaintiffs have not identified any authority for their argument that there is a 
t
S 
n
d er 17  standalone cause of action for violation of the freedom of movement.  While plaintiffs cite  
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  Nunez by Nunez v. City of San Diego, that case recognized a “fundamental right of free 
N
19  movement” only as part of an equal protection claim.  114 F.3d 935, 944 (9th Cir. 1997).   
20  Moreover, this cause of action appears to challenge only the curfew order and 
21  related arrests, which are already challenged as part of the third and fifth causes of 
22  action.  Accordingly, because plaintiffs have not adequately shown a basis for a 
23  standalone cause of action for freedom of movement, and because this cause of action is 
24  effectively duplicative of the third and fifth causes of action in this case, the court 
25  GRANTS defendants’ motion to dismiss the seventh cause of action.  Because plaintiffs 
26  have not identified any authority for treating this claim as a standalone cause of action, 
27  the dismissal shall be with prejudice.     
28   
26 

 
1  8.  Eighth cause of action (failure to intervene) 
2    “[P]olice officers have a duty to intercede when their fellow officers violate the 
3  constitutional rights of a suspect or other citizen.”  Cunningham v. Gates, 229 F.3d 1271, 
4  1289 (9th Cir. 2000).  “Importantly, however, officers can be held liable for failing to 
5  intercede only if they had an opportunity to intervene.”  Id.     
6    Defendants’ primary argument is that “plaintiffs do not state a clearly established 
7  violation based on a failure to intervene,” thus entitling them to qualified immunity.  
8  However, as stated above, the qualified immunity analysis is premature when such 
9  analysis depends on the underlying facts.  To determine whether defendants “had an 
10  opportunity to intervene,” the court first needs the factual record to be developed.  
11  Accordingly, defendants’ motion to dismiss is DENIED as to the eighth cause of action.   
 a  12  9.  Ninth cause of action (conspiracy) 
urtni
oor 13  “To establish the defendants’ liability for a conspiracy, a plaintiff must demonstrate 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  the existence of an agreement or ‘meeting of the minds' to violate constitutional rights.”  
Dict  15  Mendocino Environmental Center v. Mendocino County, 192 F.3d 1283, 1301 (9th Cir. 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  1999).   
t
S 
n
d er 17  Defendants argue that plaintiffs must plead “the existence of an agreement or 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  meeting of the minds to violate constitutional rights” and must go beyond “vague and 
N
19  conclusory conspiracy claims.”   
20  The court agrees with defendants that plaintiffs’ conspiracy-related allegations are 
21  too vague and conclusory to meet the standards for pleading.  Plaintiffs make no attempt 
22  to make specific allegations as to what role each defendant played in any conspiracy.  
23  Accordingly, defendants’ motion to dismiss the ninth cause of action is GRANTED.  The 
24  dismissal shall be without prejudice to reasserting this claim if plaintiffs learn facts 
25  through discovery that would show this claim to be viable.    
26  10.  Tenth cause of action (ADA) and eleventh cause of action (Rehabilitation 
Act) 
27 
  The Americans with Disabilities Act prohibits disability-based discrimination in the 
28 
27 

 
1  “services, programs, or activities of a public entity,” while the Rehabilitation Act prohibits 
2  disability-based discrimination in “any program or activity receiving federal financial 
3  assistance.”  42 U.S.C. § 12132; 29 U.S.C. § 794.  The Ninth Circuit has held that “[t]here 
4  is no significant difference in analysis of the rights and obligations created by the ADA 
5  and the Rehabilitation Act.”  Zukle v. Regents of University of California, 166 F.3d 1041, 
6  1045, n.11 (9th Cir. 1999).   
7    The complaint did not specify which plaintiffs assert these two claims, and also 
8  appears to assert the claims against all defendants.  See Dkt. 3, ¶¶ 280-308.  However, 
9  plaintiffs’ claim chart states that the ADA and RA claims are asserted only by plaintiff 
10  Cartwright, and against only the City of San Jose.  Dkt. 37 at 6.   
11    The Ninth Circuit has held that the ADA applies to police officers making arrests.  
 a  12  Sheehan v. City & Cty. of San Francisco, 743 F.3d 1211, 1232 (9th Cir. 2014).  
urtni
oor 13  Specifically, “where, although police properly investigate and arrest a person with a 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  disability for a crime unrelated to that disability, they fail to reasonably accommodate the 
Dict  15  person's disability in the course of investigation or arrest, causing the person to suffer 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  greater injury or indignity in that process than other arrestees,” such failure to reasonably 
t
S 
n
d er 17  accommodate violates the ADA.  Id.  Whether an accommodation is reasonable is 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  ordinarily a question of fact.  Id. at 1233.   
N
19    Defendants argue that the Ninth Circuit has only ever applied the ADA to preclude 
20  the use of deadly force on disabled suspects when non-deadly force was feasible, but 
21  there is nothing in the Sheehan opinion that so limits its holding. 
22    The complaint alleges that Cartwright has a brain injury as well as injuries to both 
23  of her knees, and alleges, in part, that she was “physically unable to run” away from 
24  officers shooting impact munitions because of her disability.  Dkt. 3, ¶¶ 20, 102.  While 
25  defendants challenge the reasonableness of any possible accommodations, that inquiry 
26  is a question of fact and cannot be resolved at the pleading stage.  Accordingly, 
27  defendants’ motion to dismiss is DENIED as to the tenth and eleventh causes of action.  
28  However, as stated above, only these claims as asserted by plaintiff Cartwright against 
28 

 
1  the City of San Jose remain in the case.   
2  11.  Remaining state law causes of action 
3  Defendants’ motion does not present separate arguments on the state law claims, 
4  instead taking the position that “plaintiffs’ state-law claims rely on the same allegations 
5  and theories of liability as in their federal claims under § 1983 and fail for the same 
6  reasons.”  Dkt. 27 at 25.   
7  As to the twelfth cause of action (Bane Act), defendants argue that it is 
8  “coextensive” with an excessive force claim except that the Bane Act also requires a 
9  showing of specific intent, but defendants do not challenge that additional requirement in 
10  their motion.  Because the court denied defendants’ motion to dismiss as to the federal 
11  excessive force claim, the court also DENIES defendants’ motion to dismiss as to the 
 a  12  twelfth cause of action under the Bane Act. 
urtni
oor 13  As to the thirteenth cause of action (Ralph Act), defendants argue it is the same as 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  a viewpoint-discrimination claim.  Because the court denied defendants’ motion to 
Dict  15  dismiss as to the federal First Amendment viewpoint-discrimination claim, the court also 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  DENIES defendants’ motion to dismiss as to the thirteenth cause of action under the 
t
S 
n
d er 17  Ralph Act. 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  As to the fourteenth cause of action for assault and battery, defendants argue it is 
N
19  the same as an excessive force claim.  Because the court denied defendants’ motion to 
20  dismiss as to the federal excessive force claim, the court also DENIES defendants’ 
21  motion to dismiss as to the fourteenth cause of action. 
22  As to the fifteenth cause of action for false arrest, defendants argue it is the same 
23  as the federal wrongful arrest claim.  Because the court denied defendants’ motion to 
24  dismiss as to the federal wrongful arrest claim, the court also DENIES defendants’ motion 
25  to dismiss as to the fifteenth cause of action. 
26  And as to the sixteenth cause of action for negligence, defendants argue it is the 
27  same as the Fourth Amendment claim.  Because the court denied defendants’ motion to 
28  dismiss as to the federal Fourth Amendment claims for excessive force and wrongful 
29 

 
1  arrest, the court also DENIES defendants’ motion to dismiss as to the sixteenth cause of 
2  action. 
3  Defendants then invoke the state-law “discretionary act immunity.”  However, as 
4  with the federal qualified immunity analysis, this analysis is better suited for summary 
5  judgment when the factual record will have been developed.  See, e.g., Conway v. City of 
6  Tuolumne, 231 Cal.App.4th 1005 (2014) (considering discretionary act immunity on a 
7  motion for summary judgment).   
8  CONCLUSION 
9    For the foregoing reasons, defendants’ motion to dismiss is GRANTED in part and 
10  DENIED in part.  The court summarizes its rulings, and the claims remaining in the case, 
11  as follows: 
 a  12    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the third cause of action for violation of the First 
urtni
oor 13  Amendment is DENIED as to the viewpoint-discrimination claim, and DENIED as to 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  the curfew-related claim as to defendants Sykes, Liccardo, Garcia, and the City of 
Dict  15  San Jose, but GRANTED without leave to amend as to the curfew-related claims as 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  to all other defendants; 
t
S 
n
d er 17    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the fourth cause of action for excessive force is 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  DENIED;  
N
19    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the fifth cause of action for wrongful arrest is DENIED; 
20    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the sixth cause of action for violation of equal 
21  protection is GRANTED without leave to amend; 
22    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the seventh cause of action for violation of the freedom 
23  of movement is GRANTED without leave to amend; 
24    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the eighth cause of action for failure to intervene is 
25  DENIED; 
26    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the ninth cause of action for conspiracy is GRANTED 
27  without prejudice to reasserting this claim with more facts should discovery reveal that 
28  it is viable; 
30 

 
1    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the tenth and eleventh causes of action for violations of 
2  the ADA and RA is DENIED; 
3    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the twelfth cause of action for violation of the Bane Act 
4  is DENIED; 
5    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the thirteenth cause of action for violation of the Ralph 
6  Act is DENIED; 
7    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the fourteenth cause of action for assault and battery is 
8  DENIED; 
9    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the fifteenth cause of action for false arrest is DENIED; 
10  and 
11    Defendants’ motion to dismiss the sixteenth cause of action for negligence is 
 a  12  DENIED. 
urtni
oor 13  That leaves the following claims remaining in the case: 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14    First cause of action for injunctive relief and second cause of action for declaratory 
Dict  15  relief, which are types of remedies and were not at issue on this motion; 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16    Third cause of action for First Amendment violation: 
t
S 
n
d er 17  -  Viewpoint discrimination claim, asserted by all plaintiffs against all defendants; 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  -  Curfew-related claim, asserted by all plaintiffs against defendants Sykes, 
N
19  Liccardo, Garcia, and City of San Jose; 
20    Fourth cause of action for excessive force, asserted by all plaintiffs against all 
21  defendants; 
22    Fifth cause of action for wrongful arrest, asserted by plaintiffs Cartwright, Lee,

26  defendants Dwyer, Garcia, Sykes, Yuen, Curry, and Delgado; 
27    Tenth cause of action for violation of the ADA, asserted by plaintiff Cartwright against 
28  defendant City of San Jose;

2  against defendant City of San Jose;

      Defendants.

21  NOTICE OF MOTION  
22  Please take notice that on June 1, 2023, or as soon as this matter can be heard, all Defendants 
23  will and hereby do move pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56 for summary judgment on all 
24  claims brought by all Plaintiffs. 
25  This motion is based on the attached memorandum of points and authorities, all materials 
26  submitted in conjunction herewith, and any other materials or information that should come to the 
27  Court’s attention as part of this proceeding. 
28   
 
 
DEFENDANTS’ NOTICE OF MOTION   21-cv-01705-PJH 
AND MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
2009333_2 
 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 121   Filed 04/14/23   Page 2 of 61
 
1  Statement of Issues to Be Decided 
 
2 
1.  To prove excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment, a plaintiff must show that an 
3 
officer intentionally used force against her with the objective purpose to restrain, and that the 
4 
force was unreasonable.  Are Defendants entitled to judgment as a matter of law on Plaintiffs’ 
5 
excessive force claims here where: (a) most Plaintiffs were struck by police, if at all, by 
6 
accident; (b) the circumstances of officers’ force in all but one case objectively manifested a 
7  purpose to disperse or repel rather than restrain; and (c) in the one case involving a purposeful 
8  detention, the officer believed the plaintiff had dangerous objects and pushed him to effect an 
arrest after the plaintiff tried to run away? 
9 
10 
2.  The central element of a First Amendment retaliation claim is speech-based animus by the 
11  defendant.  Here, no Defendant said anything to express adversity or hostility to Plaintiffs’ 
speech activity, and Plaintiffs have identified no other evidence of retaliatory animus.  Are 
12 
Defendants entitled to judgment as a matter of law on Plaintiffs’ First Amendment retaliation 
13 
claims? 
14 
15  3.  To hold a supervisory official liable for the constitutional violations of a subordinate, a plaintiff 
must at a minimum prove that the supervisor caused the violations through deliberate 
16 
indifference, meaning that the supervisor knew his conduct would result in a subordinate 
17 
violating the Constitution yet consciously chose to allow that violation.  Here, Plaintiffs have no 
18 
evidence that any supervisory official ordered, authorized, or consciously allowed a subordinate 
19 
to violate any Plaintiff’s constitutional rights.  Are the supervisory officials entitled to judgment 
20 
as a matter of law on Plaintiff’s constitutional claims?  
21 
4.  Qualified immunity prohibits liability for police officers unless controlling authority or a robust 
22 
consensus of persuasive authority put them on notice that their particular conduct violated the 
23 
Constitution.  Here, Plaintiffs can point to no case in which a police officer was held to have 
24 
violated the Constitution under circumstances resembling those faced by Defendants: i.e., a 
25  violent unlawful assembly in which officers are required to disperse the crowd and restore order 
with force.  Nor have Plaintiffs pointed to any case holding a supervisory official liable in such 
26 
a context.  Can Plaintiffs overcome the protections of qualified immunity to hold Defendants 
27 
liable? 
28 
 
DEFENDANTS’ NOTICE OF MOTION   21-cv-01705-PJH 
AND MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
2009333_2 
 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 121   Filed 04/14/23   Page 3 of 61
 
5.  A city cannot be held liable for the constitutional violations of its employees unless an official 
1 
policy, endorsed by its highest policymaking officials, caused the violations.  Here, the City had 
2 
explicit policies that prohibited excessive force and unlawful retaliation and required all officers 
3 
to be trained specifically in the weapons they used during the unlawful assembly.  There is also 
4 
no evidence that San Jose officers had engaged in excessive force or unlawful retaliation at any 
5 
past expressive event.  Is the City of San Jose entitled to judgment as a matter of law on 
6  Plaintiffs’ municipal liability claim?  
7 
6.  For a failure-to-accommodate claim, the Americans with Disabilities and Rehabilitation Acts 
8 
require a plaintiff affirmatively to prove that a reasonable accommodation existed, was known 
9 
to the city defendant, and was denied.  Here, a police officer pushed Plaintiff Cartwright away 
10  three times after she disobeyed his order to get back from a moving police line.  Cartwright said 
11  that she had an unspecified brain injury in between one of these pushes, but she did not tell the 
officer she had a disability or suggest any accommodation he should provide.  Is the City 
12 
entitled to judgment as a matter of law on Cartwright’s federal disability claims? 
13 
14  7.  Plaintiffs predicate their state-law claims on the same allegations and theories as their federal 
constitutional claims.  Are Defendants entitled to judgment as a matter of law on the state-law 
15 
claims as a result, and if not, do the immunities in California law for police tactical decisions 
16 
during an unlawful riot independently preclude liability on those claims? 
17 
 
18

1  Introduction 
2    On May 29, 2020, what began as a protest in downtown San Jose quickly devolved into a 
3  violent riot.  Protesters took over streets and highways, assaulted civilians and police officers, and 
4  destroyed public and private property.  In the attempt to restore order, San Jose police declared an 
5  unlawful assembly and ordered protesters to disperse.  Few heeded that order.  On the contrary, 
6  protesters responded by screaming at and escalating their assaults on police officers, including by 
7  knocking one police officer unconscious.  Police responded by using force, both to disperse and move 
8  the crowd and also to target those who were actively assaulting officers by throwing objects.  
9  Ultimately, the City had to declare a state of emergency given the rampant lawlessness it faced.  
10    The Plaintiffs in this case were all present amid this violent and unlawful assembly.  Each had 
11  been ordered to disperse multiple times yet chose to remain downtown.  And each now claims one or 
12  more of the 22 named Defendants used or caused force against him or her in violation of the First and 
13  Fourth Amendment (and state law).  Plaintiffs’ claims cannot survive summary judgment.  
14    Plaintiffs’ excessive force claims against the various Defendants are scattershot and consist 
15  largely of guesswork.  Plaintiffs do not know what police officer, if any, was responsible for the 
16  violations they assert, so they name multiple officers in multiple claims as part of an undifferentiated 
17  monolith.  Yet the undisputed facts are that most Plaintiffs were struck by a police projectile, if at all, 
18  by an unknown officer, and even then only by accident.  It follows that these Plaintiffs cannot prove 
19  any Defendant intentionally used force against him or her, much less that any officer did so with the 
20  objective purpose to restrain (rather than to disperse or repel).  As to the Plaintiffs who have identified 
21  officers who intentionally used force, that force was a reasonable response to the officers’ reasonable 
22  perception that the Plaintiffs had engaged in obstructive or assaultive conduct.  Because no Plaintiff can 
23  prove both a seizure and unreasonableness, Plaintiffs’ Fourth Amendment claims necessarily fail.   
24    The record precludes Plaintiffs’ First Amendment claim for the simple reason that they have no 
25  evidence to suggest any Defendant secretly harbored retaliatory animus against them.  Defendants 
26  faced hundreds of protesters over the course of the protest.  There is no basis for the inference that, of 
27  all these individuals engaging in the same protest activity, Defendants targeted Plaintiffs in particular to 
28  punish them for their speech.  Plaintiffs therefore cannot prove unlawful retaliation.  
1

2009333_2 
 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 121   Filed 04/14/23   Page 12 of 61
 
1    Plaintiffs’ claim against the City of San Jose likewise fails.  City policy before May 2020 was 
2  explicit and extensive in prohibiting excessive force and viewpoint discrimination.  Training and policy 
3  in the City also delineated with particularity the circumstances under which force—including projectile 
4  weapons—could be used safely and effectively, in the crowd-control context or any other.  Indeed, it is 
5  precisely because the City’s policies and training so effectively prevented misconduct during public 
6  demonstrations that Plaintiffs have not adduced evidence of a single instance in which a San Jose 
7  police officer has every violated a protester’s rights through excessive force or unlawful retaliation.  
8  Plaintiffs’ municipal liability claim is meritless.  
9    The standalone claims of one Plaintiff (Cartwright) under federal disability law based on a 
10  purported failure to accommodate must also be dismissed.  Plaintiffs have pointed to no possible 
11  accommodation Cartwright was denied at the protest, and indeed Cartwright herself has admitted she 
12  neither requested nor was denied accommodation there.  Under no proper conception of applicable 
13  federal law did the City violate Cartwright’s rights through a failure to accommodate.  
14    Finally, Plaintiffs’ state-law claims rely on the same theories and allegations as their federal 
15  constitutional claims, so they fail for the same reason.  They fail for the additional reason that state-law 
16  immunities preclude liability for tactical decision during a riot of the type Defendants face here.  
17    All Defendants are entitled to judgment as a law.  They request an order so holding.  
18  Factual Background 
19  I.  San Jose Police Department policies on crowd control and the use of force 
20  The San Jose Police Department’s (“SJPD”) policies and training before May 29, 2020 
21  regarding the use of projectile impact weapons (“PIW”) and other force during crowd-control events 
22  were robust and specific.  The policies were codified in the 2020 SJPD Duty Manual (“DM”), which all 
23  police officers were required to know.  Tassio Dec., ¶ 1. The DM defined objectively reasonable force 
24  and prohibited police officers from using excessive force, whether in a crowd-control situation or any 
25  other.  Id. ¶ 5.   The DM also contained specific provisions regarding protests, riots, and other crowd-
26  control scenarios.  Id. ¶¶ 2-3.  The DM further cautioned police officers that protests and 
27  demonstrations are emotional events that require calmness and objectivity, and it explicitly mandated 
28  “equal treatment” of any “demonstrators” whom officers encounter.  Id. ¶ 2.  Officers were instructed 
2

2009333_2 
 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 121   Filed 04/14/23   Page 13 of 61
 
1  not to interfere with any person, whether formal media or just a member of the public, who wished to 
2  take video or photographs in normally accessible areas.  Id. ¶ 3.   
3  Also included in the DM was an outline of the tools commonly available to assist law 
4  enforcement in the singular and difficult task of controlling violent crowds.  These tools, which are 
5  used by police officers across the country, include: batons, often as part of the effort to move groups of 
6  people with a police line; oleoresin capsicum (OC) cannisters; teargas cannisters; and PIW.  The PIW 
7  available to SJPD officers and outlined in the DM were the 37mm projectile launcher (“37mm”); 
8  40mm launchers (shooting foam baton rounds (“40mm”) and OC rounds); and a beanbag shotgun.  Id. 
9  ¶ 6 & Ex. 2; Pritchard Dec., Ex. 3, 81:19-25.  Each of these tools is different, and the DM instructed 
10  police officers about when it was appropriate or inappropriate to use them.  Id. 
11  The 37mm is used as an indirect crowd-control device.  Id. Ex. 1 82:11-89:9.  It functions by 
12  allowing a police officer to fire a round against the ground in front of a group of people, which impact 
13  causes the round to disperse five small foam discs outward.  Id. Ex. 2, 55:1-22, 65:24-66:4.  Each of the 
14  discs is slightly larger than a quarter.  See id.  The 37mm is designed not to cause serious injury; its 
15  purpose is more to startle and disorient a crowd than to inflict force—when the 37mm is fired, it emits 
16  a loud noise and smoke.  Id. Ex. 1 105:9-25.  The action of skipping the projectile off the ground before 
17  the discs disperse causes most of the forceful energy of the discs to dissipate, meaning that the force of 
18  any impact on a person is significantly minimized.  Id. 82:11-89:9.  All officers trained to use 37mm 
19  launchers are themselves subjected to its force, meaning that they are personally fired upon and 
20  experience the resulting impact.  Tassio Dec., ¶ 15. 
21  The DM specifies that the 37mm may be used for crowd-control only by special operations 
22  officers specifically trained on that device, and such officers may deploy it only after (1) an unlawful 
23  assembly and dispersal order has been given; (2) a commanding officer has authorized deployment and 
24  use of the 37mm; and (3) the 37mm is fired at a sufficient distance from the crowd to ensure the energy 
25  of the projectile will have sufficiently dissipated to prevent substantial injury.  Tassio Dec., Ex. 2.  
26  The 40mm (along with the beanbag shotgun), by contrast, is intended to be used not for general 
27  crowd control but to target specific individuals.  Pritchard Dec., Ex. 1 at 95:10-20.  The 40mm is used 
28  by firing one foam baton directly at a subject.  Id.  The DM provides that officers may not use the

1  40mm unless they have completed an approved training course on it, and it prohibits its use except to 
2  prevent serious injury.  Tassio Dec., Ex. 2.  The 40mm OC rounds have the same caliber as the 40mm 
3  foam baton rounds, but they contain OC powder, the same chemical agent in pepper spray.  Pritchard 
4  Dec., Ex. 3 305:21-306:5.  The 40mm OC rounds can be used as a direct impact weapon, in which case 
5  they are subject to the same rules and restraints as the 40mm foam batons, but OC rounds are also used 
6  indirectly for crowd dispersal purposes.  Pritchard Dec., Ex. 1 114: 2-114:18.  Such indirect use 
7  involves the officer firing an OC round against a hard surface near or above an unlawful assembly of 
8  people, and the impact of the projectile causes OC powder to release in the area of the crowd.  Id.  
9  Teargas is contained in cannisters.  To use it, police officers throw the cannister in the direction 
10  of an unlawful assembly, after which it releases a smoky gas.  Pritchard Dec., Ex. 4 112:7-19.  The gas 
11  acts as an irritant on the surrounding crowd and is designed to induce its members to leave the area.  
12  Pritchard Dec., Ex. 5 78:5-7, 83:6-83:23. 
13  II.  San Jose Police Department training on crowd control and the use of force 
14  All law enforcement agencies in California must by law comply with the state’s Peace Officer 
15  Standards and Training, or “POST,” requirements.  E.g., Cal. Code Regs. tit. 11, § 1005.  Any person 
16  in the state who wishes to become a police officer must be POST certified.  Id. § 1950.  Certification 
17  entails a rigorous course of training, particularly on issues related to the use of force.  See Sciba Dec. 
18  ¶¶ 4-8.  Further, to maintain POST certification after it has been granted, officers must successfully 
19  complete continuing professionally training requirements every two years.  Id. ¶ 4. 
20  The SJPD’s training program and requirements before May 2020 exceeded those prescribed by 
21  POST.  Id. ¶ 6.  All officers with SJPD were required to complete a 26-week Police Academy, which 
22  entails approximately 976 hours of training.  Id. Officers were taught about the definition and real-
23  world meaning of objectively reasonable force, including the force appropriate in response to different 
24  levels of resistance.  Id. ¶ 7. Officers were taught the proper way to use different force techniques, from 
25  the use of hands and control holds, batons, non-lethal weapons, and firearms.  Id. ¶ 6.  In addition to 
26  POST certification, SJPD officers were required to complete a four-hour course devoted specifically to 
27  the use of PIW.  Id. ¶ 9. This special course taught officers how to use PIW properly, under what 
28  circumstances they are appropriate, and how best to minimize serious injury.  Id.  Officers were taught
