1  defendant Dwyer.  However, because plaintiffs Swift and Allen do not have viable 
2  allegations of being struck with PIW, summary judgment is GRANTED as to the Fourth 
3  Amendment claim brought by plaintiffs Swift and Allen against defendant Dwyer.   
4      c.  Matchett 
5    Plaintiffs’ opposition brief includes only one paragraph on defendant Matchett, 
6  arguing that he gave the order to push the crowd at a certain intersection.  See Dkt. 128 
7  at 51.  Plaintiffs do not provide any evidence that Matchett was personally involved with 
8  the specific violations alleged by plaintiffs Acosta, Vasquez, and Flores – namely, the use 
9  of PIW.  Nor do plaintiffs adequately tie Matchett’s conduct to the alleged excessive force 
10  used against Swift and Allen at Cesar Chavez Park.  Thus, the court concludes that 
11  defendants’ motion for summary judgment must be GRANTED as to the Fourth 
 a  12  Amendment claim asserted against defendant Matchett.  And, for the same reasons

5      e.  Lopez

7  supervisor of defendants Yuen and Situ at the scene of the protests.  Because plaintiff 
8  Vasquez has no viable claim against either defendants Yuen or Situ, she also has no

11    Plaintiffs Acosta and Allen do have a viable Fourth Amendment claim against 
 a  12  defendant Yuen, and because defendants have conceded that Lopez directly supervised

24      g.  Monell claim against the City 
25    To the extent that plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores have viable 
26  Fourth Amendment claims against individual defendants, the court will also evaluate 
27  whether those plaintiffs can also assert a viable Fourth Amendment claim against the City 
28  of San Jose under a Monell theory.   
28 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 147   Filed 08/03/23   Page 29 of 34
 
1    “The Supreme Court in Monell held that municipalities may only be held liable 
2  under section 1983 for constitutional violations resulting from official . . . policy or 
3  custom.”  Benavidez v. County of San Diego, 993 F.3d 1134, 1153 (9th Cir. 2021) (citing 
4  Monell v. Dep’t of Soc. Servs. of City of New York, 436 U.S. 658, 694 (1978)).  The policy 
5  or custom must be a “deliberate choice to follow a course of action . . . made from among 
6  various alternatives by the official or officials responsible for establishing final policy with 
7  respect to the subject matter in question.”  Id. at 1153 (citing Castro v. County of Los 
8  Angeles, 833 F.3d 1060, 1075 (9th Cir. 2016)).  
9    Plaintiffs argue that the City’s choice to allow use of 37mm and 40mm PIW against 
10  protestors, which had not been used at any protest before, was an unconstitutional 
11  policy.  Defendants argue that plaintiffs cannot establish an unconstitutional policy or 
 a  12  custom based only on a single instance of conduct.  See Dkt. 121 at 56.  However, the 
urtni
oor 13  Supreme Court has held that “it is plain that municipal liability may be imposed for a 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  single decision by municipal policymakers under appropriate circumstances.”  Pembaur 
Dict  15  v. City of Cincinnati, 475 U.S. 469, 480 (1986); see also McRorie v. Shimoda, 795 F.2d 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  780, 784 (9th Cir. 1986), Menotti v, City of Seattle, 409 F.3d 1113, 1147 (9th Cir. 2005).   
t
S 
n

e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  use of PIW, and because plaintiffs Swift and Allen do not have viable claims arising out of 
N
19  the use of PIW, summary judgment is GRANTED as to all claims asserted by Swift and 
20  Allen against the City. 
21    As to plaintiffs Acosta, Vasquez, and Flores, the court concludes that plaintiffs 
22  have raised a triable issue as to whether the City of San Jose’s policy or custom of using 
23  PIW against non-threatening protestors was unconstitutional under the law established 
24  by the Ninth Circuit in Nelson and related cases.  Thus, the motion for summary judgment 
25  is DENIED as to the Fourth Amendment claim brought under Monell against the City of 
26  San Jose by plaintiffs Acosta, Vasquez, and Flores.    
27    14.  First Amendment 
28    As discussed above, for those plaintiffs whose excessive force claims were 
29 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 147   Filed 08/03/23   Page 30 of 34
 
1  deemed unviable, their First Amendment claims are also unviable.  However, because 
2  plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores do have viable excessive force claims, 
3  the court will now also consider whether they have viable First Amendment claims. 
4    To prevail on a First Amendment claim, a plaintiff must show that (1) he was 
5  engaged in constitutionally protected activity, (2) defendants’ conduct would chill a 
6  person of ordinary firmness from continuing to participate in the protected activity, and (3) 
7  the protected activity was a “substantial or motivating factor” in the defendants’ conduct.  
8  See, e.g., Index Newspapers v. U.S. Marshals, 977 F.3d 817, 827 (9th Cir. 2020).  The 
9  “substantial or motivating factor” element “may be met with either direct or circumstantial 
10  evidence, and we have said that it involves questions of fact that normally should be left 
11  for trial.”  Id. at 827 (citing Ulrich v. City & County of San Francisco, 308 F.3d 968, 979 
 a  12  (9th Cir. 2002)). 
urtni
oor 13    Plaintiffs’ argument relies largely on circumstantial evidence.  While they cite 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  individual examples of police officers expressing negative views of protestors, the court 
Dict  15  will not impute each of those statements to every officer in the San Jose Police 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  Department.  That said, the court also recognizes, as did the Sanderlin court, that “it 
t
S 
n
d er 17  would be difficult for plaintiffs to produce direct evidence that the officers’ subjective 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  motives for the shooting were related to the protests and their subject matters.”  
N
19  Sanderlin, 2023 WL 2562400 at *16.  The court further recognizes the unique factual 
20  circumstances presented by this case, where the parties alleged to have used excessive 
21  force are themselves the subject of the plaintiffs’ viewpoint expression.  Thus, there is an 
22  inherently oppositional nature between the viewpoint and the police, in contrast with 
23  cases where the viewpoint being expressed is unrelated to the police.  
24    Overall, when considering the specific officers for whom a triable issue has been 
25  raised as to the reasonableness of their use of force, the court concludes that a 
26  reasonable jury could find that the plaintiffs’ viewpoint expression was a “substantial or 
27  motivating factor” in the uses of force.  However, the court’s conclusion is limited to the 
28  specific officers alleged to have actually applied the force to the remaining plaintiffs, 
30 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 147   Filed 08/03/23   Page 31 of 34
 
1  Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores.  As to the supervisory defendants and the City, 
2  plaintiffs have not provided the court with a basis for concluding that the plaintiffs’ 
3  viewpoint was a “substantial or motivating factor” in any of the supervisors’ conduct, or in 
4  any policy or custom adopted by the City, including the use of PIW.   
5    Accordingly, defendants’ motion for summary judgment as to the First Amendment 
6  claim is DENIED to the extent it is asserted by Acosta against Yuen, by Swift against 
7  Curry and Ayala, by Vasquez against Simonini, by Allen against Yuen, and by Flores 
8  against Gaona.  As to all other First Amendment claims asserted against all other 
9  defendants, the motion for summary judgment is GRANTED.   
10    15.  Failure to intervene – fifth cause of action 
11    As mentioned above, plaintiffs’ complaint purports to assert a fifth cause of action 
 a  12  for ‘failure to intervene’ under section 1983.  Plaintiffs’ opposition devotes only a single 
urtni
oor 13  paragraph to this cause of action, arguing that defendants Yuen, Grodin, Nguyen, 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  Simonini, and Preuss failed to intervene in the First Amendment violations of plaintiffs 
Dict  15  Acosta and Riles.  See Dkt. 128 at 29.  The court has already concluded that Riles has 
s ri
et
s
atDi 16  no viable claim for a First Amendment violation, and as to Acosta, plaintiffs’ do not 
t
S 
n
d er 17  present the court with any basis for concluding that any defendants had a realistic 
e
h
t
nirt
Uo 18  opportunity to intervene to prevent the single shot that struck him, which plaintiffs admit 
N
19  occurred “within seconds of commands to move the line forward.”  See Dkt. 128 at 28; 
20  see also Cunningham v. Gates, 229 F.3d 1271, 1289 (9th Cir. 2000) (“officers can be 
21  held liable for failing to intercede only if they had an opportunity to intercede”); Cortesluna 
22  v. Leon, 979 F.3d 645, 656 (9th Cir. 2020) (“there is no evidence that [the officer] knew 
23  what the other defendants would do, and the events unfolded very rapidly – in a matter of 
24  seconds”).  Accordingly, defendants’ motion for summary judgment is GRANTED as to 
25  plaintiffs’ fifth cause of action for failure to intervene.    
26    16.  State law claims 
27    The parties agree that plaintiffs’ state law claims are premised on the same 
28  theories and evidence as their federal § 1983 claims, and thus largely rise and fall 
31 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 147   Filed 08/03/23   Page 32 of 34
 
1  together.   
2    A Bane Act claim has the same elements as an excessive force claim under the 
3  Fourth Amendment, with an additional requirement that the defendant intended to 
4  interfere with a plaintiff’s constitutional rights.  See Reese v. County of Sacramento, 888 
5  F.3d 1030, 1045 (9th Cir. 2018).  The Reese court also made clear that the “intent” 
6  requirement can be met by “a reckless disregard for a person’s constitutional rights.”  Id.  
7  Defendants argue that the intent requirement cannot be met here, but the court 
8  concludes that, as to the defendants against whom plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, 
9  Allen, and Flores have a viable Fourth Amendment claim, plaintiffs can show “reckless 
10  disregard” for their constitutional rights for the same reasons that the court denied 
11  qualified immunity – namely, that plaintiffs had a clearly established right to be free from 
 a  12  the force that was used against them in the circumstances they were in.  Thus, to the 
urtni
oor 13  extent that summary judgment was denied as to the Fourth Amendment claim brought by 
Cf
t ali
stricof C 14  plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores, summary judgment is also DENIED 
Dict  15  as to the Bane Act claim brought by those plaintiffs.

et

t
S 
n
d er 17  complaint as brought under a viewpoint-discrimination theory.  See Dkt. 108 at 56.  Thus, 
e
h

nirt
Uo 18  to the extent that summary judgment was denied as to the First Amendment claim 
N
19  brought by plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores, summary judgment is also 
20  DENIED as to the Ralph Act claim brought by those plaintiffs.   
21    Finally, plaintiffs assert state law claims for assault and battery, and for 
22  negligence.  Both are coextensive with a Fourth Amendment excessive force claim, and 
23  to the extent that the court denied summary judgment as to the Fourth Amendment claim 
24  brought by plaintiffs Acosta, Swift, Vasquez, Allen, and Flores, summary judgment is also

26  plaintiffs.

28   
 
NO. 4:21-CV-01705 PJH FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 108   Filed 02/27/23   Page 2 of 59
 
 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1  1.  Black people have been hunted, brutalized and killed by the police since the inception 
2  of law enforcement in the United States, including a demonstrable history of violence in San 
José. This action arises out of protests across the nation in response to the May 25, 2020, 
3 
murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis Police Department officers. Floyd’s death, so soon 
4 
after law enforcement killed Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery, mobilized millions of 
5 
people around the country to condemn the deaths of Black and Brown people by law 
6 
enforcement in one of the largest social justice movements in U.S. history.1  
7 
2.  In San José, thousands of demonstrators took to the streets on May 29, 2020, and for 
8  several days thereafter, to express their view that police brutality and institutionalized racism 
9  must end. But the demonstrators were met with brutal and racially targeted repression by 
10  defendant CITY OF SAN JOSÉ.  
11  3.  This is a civil rights action for damages, injunctive and declaratory relief arising from 
unconstitutional CITY OF SAN JOSÉ Police’s violence on May 29-31, 2020. Named plaintiffs 
12 
M. MICHAEL ACOSTA, JOSEPH MALDONADO, MAHMOUDREZA NAEMEH and 
13 
 
MEGAN SWIFT (suing as individuals), and JOSEPH CAÑAS, LESLIE VASQUEZ, PETER 
14 
ALLEN, SHAUNN CARTWRIGHT, YESSICA RILES, JOSÉ GUSTAVO FLORES 
15 
RODRIGUEZ, and CINDY CUELLAR, (suing as individuals and class representatives) seek 
16 
redress for the violation of their constitutional rights to assemble, protest, and be free from 
17  racial discrimination, disability discrimination, excessive force, and wrongful arrest. 
18  Organization plaintiffs NAACP OF SAN JOSÉ / SILICON VALLEY and SAN JOSÉ PEACE 
19  AND JUSTICE CENTER, along with all of the individual plaintiffs, seek prospective and 
20  declaratory relief to ensure the right to express viewpoints critical of the police or government 
in San José without fear of violent repression or wrongful arrest. 
21 
4.  Starting on May 29, 2020, and continuing during the demonstrations on May 30, 31, 
22 
and thereafter, the CITY OF SAN JOSÉ Police fired impact munitions into the bodies of 
23 
unarmed, predominately peaceful demonstrators, observers and journalists without 
24 
justification; threw explosive flash-bang and “stinger” grenades at them; attacked them with 
25 
chemical weapons; and beat them with hands and batons.  
26 
 
27  1Larry Buchanan, Quoctrung Bui, and Jugal K. Patel, Black Lives Matter May Be the Largest Movement in U.S. 
History, N.Y. Times (Jul. 3, 2020), https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/07/03/us/george-floyd-protests-
28  crowd-size.html. 
 
 
CASE NO. 4:21-CV-01705 PJH   FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT         2 
 

Case 4:21-cv-01705-PJH   Document 108   Filed 02/27/23   Page 3 of 59
 
 
 
5.  Impact munitions are widely known to cause serious harm. These munitions, also 
known as Projectile Impact Weapons (PIW), Specialty Impact Munitions (SIM), or Kinetic 
1 
Impact Projectiles (KIP), can cause fractures, serious organ injuries, and death, especially 
2 
when the point of impact is the head, neck, or torso.2 Two of the plaintiffs in this case were 
3 
struck in the eye: plaintiff M. MICHAEL ACOSTA lost his eye entirely, and plaintiff JOSEPH 
4 
CAÑAS sustained permanent vision impairment. Police also shot several plaintiffs with impact 
5  munitions in the groin area. The groin is another area where impact munitions can cause 
6  serious injuries or death if shot into.3  
7  6.  The CITY and its Police Department failed to establish policies to mitigate the risk of 
8  harm from impact munitions, were intentionally indifferent to the risk of these harms, and 
caused Plaintiffs’ injuries. Indeed, the CITY OF SAN JOSÉ has admitted that “[c]rowd control 
9 
training has been minimal and infrequent” and that most of the commanders and officers 
10 
assigned to the events at issue in this case were not trained adequately.4 
11 
7.  The CITY OF SAN JOSÉ Police have a long history of targeting Black, Brown, and 
12 
Muslim communities, or people who they perceive as such, for racially discriminatory 
13 
p olicing, and unreasonable force. The pattern and practice of racially discriminatory policing

235.  The Americans with Disabilities Act and its implementing regulations provide that “no 
qualified individual with a disability shall, by reason of such disability, be excluded from 
1 
participation in or be denied the benefits of the services, programs, or activities of a public entity, 
2 
or be subjected to discrimination by any such entity.” 42 U.S.C. § 12132; 28 C.F.R. § 35.149. 
3 
Title II’s requirements extend to “anything a public entity does,” including arrests and other law 
4 
enforcement interactions. 8 C.F.R. § 35, app. B. Despite these requirements, Defendants violated 
5  the ADA and its implementing regulations in multiple ways. 
6  236.  Defendants have an affirmative obligation to make benefits, services, and programs 
7  accessible to people with disabilities. § 35.150. “The general regulatory obligation to modify 
8  policies, practices, or procedures requires law enforcement to make changes in policies that 
result in discriminatory arrests or abuse of individuals with disabilities.” 28 C.F.R. pt. 35, app. B. 
9 
Defendants, however, have failed to make reasonable modifications that will make law 
10 
enforcement’s actions equally accessible to people with disabilities; indeed, their responses to 
11 
protests actively deny people with disabilities their rights at protests. 
12 
237.  Title II protects people with disabilities against facially neutral policies that burden 
13 
p eople with disabilities more than others, by requiring that the public entity provide reasonable 
14  modifications to avoid the discrimination unless the public entity can demonstrate that such 
15  modifications would result in a fundamental alteration of the program. 28 C.F.R. § 35.130(b)(7); 
16  Crowder v. Kitagaw, 81 F. 3d 1480 (9th Cir. 1996).
